Award.AwardTitle: Student Poster Symposium at the ASME International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition (ASME-IMECE); San Diego California; November 15-21, 2013

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this award is to provide partial travel support for 58 graduate and undergraduate students to attend the American Society of Mechanical Engineers International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition in San Diego, California, from November 15-21, 2013. The student will participate in a poster symposium to present their research projects to the broader Mechanical Engineering community. The students will be selected on the basis of an application including a brief resume, a one-page statement of why they want to attend the conference, and a statement of support from their faculty advisor. Consideration in the selection process will be given to inclusion of members of underrepresented groups and diversity of institutions that the students represent.

This participation support is expected to benefit students' professional, scientific and technical development. Attendance at the conference will give the students a broader view of the engineering profession and of state-of-the-art research in their fields via access to approximately 2000 technical and professional development talks by domestic and international speakers. Students will enhance their communication skills via lively discussions of their work with the top researchers in their fields during the Society-wide Poster Symposium and the Micro and Nano Forum. This interactive experience will significantly broaden their education, increase their enthusiasm for their research topic, acquaint them with expectations for scientific careers, and expose them to new avenues for innovative research. This award will benefit the nation through the education of a skilled and diverse engineering workforce better prepared to provide transformative solutions the challenges of their chosen fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Forty-six young, talented researchers working in engineering fields related to nanotechnology and assorted Mechanical Engineering-related topics were supported under this grant to showcase their research in two high-profile, interactive technical poster symposia at the 2013 ASME International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition (IMECE) gathering in San Diego, California.  The participant support costs fulfill NSF’s intellectual merit objective via stimulating scientific interactions between students and technical field leaders, and NSF’s broader impacts objective via financial support for a diverse group of students who might otherwise not have the opportunity to participate in a conference that attracts an international audience. The two poster symposia – the Society-Wide Micro and Nanotechnology Forum, and the NSF Student General Poster Symposium – highlighted the students’ research activities and were highly attended by the conference attendees. The students of the top three posters for each session, as judged by field leaders, received certificates. Student researchers were funded to attend the congress in order to acquire new, cutting-edge technical knowledge both specific to and peripherally related to their field of research, and to promote meaningful interactions between these young student academics and academic and industry leaders in their fields. Anecdotal student comments heavily emphasized these interactions with conference attendees and new knowledge gained during technical sessions.

This grant enhanced U.S. education and research infrastructure by investing in the development of future scientific leaders and via exposure to topics critical to society. Students attended keynote lectures centered on issues of national importance, including advanced manufacturing, innovation and production, 3-D printing, engineering for space exploration, and nanotechnology development. Moreover, the students gained valuable experience and honed their skills to communicate their research results to the general academic community and to receive targeted critiques of their work that will spur improvements in their ongoing research efforts. These students thereby enhanced their skills and talents that will serve to strengthen their future research productivity and retain them within their respective scientific and technical fields.
